Does Believing the Bible Make You Irrational?
Does Believing the Bible Make You Irrational?
 
 "The Bible said it, I believe it, that settles it," proclaims a common Christian bumper sticker. Strong belief in the Bible is considered a mark of spiritual maturity in most conservative Christian churches. Christians esteem that person in the congregation who is able to back up everything he or she says with a verse, whose Bible pages are yellow and wrinkled from flipping through them so often.
 
 Outsiders, however, are likely to see a person with whom they cannot reason. What in the church is considered a virtue is to them a vice. "The Bible said it and that settles it"? Apparently the Bible is only good for making one impervious to rational persuasion, they conclude. Or for enabling one conveniently to cut the argument short. People begin to suspect that perhaps the Bible is only useful for those who refuse to think, or for those wanting to justify their own bigotry.
 
 If many Christians seem difficult to reason with, it is probably true that they don't know how to think, and there probably are many people who do have bigotry they want to justify. This may have less to do with their Christianity than with the reality that this is simply the way most people are, regardless of whether or not they are Christians. Christians seem to make up the greater population of ignorant and bigoted people simply because they are more vocal and shameless in airing their true opinions. The common decency that restrains most people from saying what they really think has little stronghold on the person who is convinced that offending people with judgmental pronouncements is what it means to take a stand for God.
 
 Of course, most people don't care about the private opinions of others. They just want people to be civil enough to not to express them in hurtful and inappropriate ways. Here, I grant, Christians have failed far more miserably than the rest of the population.
 
 Why are Christians so bent on airing their views? Many Christians are actually told that it doesn't matter that they lack reasoning skills, or that they know little about other religious and philosophical worldviews. All that matters is that they know the truth of the Bible, and this is apparently reason enough for people to listen to them whether or not they are making much sense. They are not to be shy about inviting themselves even into arenas of debate where they are clearly in above their heads. Such persons imagine that they are bringing God's truth into the discussion, when in reality all they are doing is confirming to everyone involved that there must surely be a relationship between simple-mindedness and Christian belief.
 
 One might think that this only proves that the Bible does make people irrational. For since the Bible claims to be the truth, even the authoritative word of God, people who believe they have the truth will naturally want to impose it upon everyone else. Such a person has little use for the process of reasoning because all that matters to him is the bottom line. He has already looked up the answer in the back of the book; why then the need to show his work? Everyone is just supposed to take his word for it.
 
 Case in point: The Bible uses some pretty strong language to condemn same-sex sexual relations. How then can homosexuality be unchosen? If it is unchosen, we Christians reason, that seems to imply there is no moral culpability involved in homosexual behavior, and that goes against biblical teaching. So because the claims of homosexuals don't appear to match up with the view of the Bible, we tell ourselves we don't need to listen to them because we know better. Even in the face of an overwhelming consensus among homosexuals from all walks of life that their homosexual inclination is involuntary, we go to great lengths to deny what others are coming quite undramatically to accept. Perhaps the reason we assert and reassert our arguments in shrill and authoritative tones is that we are hoping no one will notice the shallow basis upon which they are built.
 
 Many Christians arrive at such a place not because of their belief in the Bible per se, but because they believe in a certain view of the Bible. Believing the Bible can make you irrational only if you view it as merely an answer book and do not think there is a rationale behind its teachings. This means that if the promptings of common sense contradict what the Bible seems to be saying, you will tend to ignore them instead of considering whether there is something deeper in the biblical text that needs to be investigated. Those common sense promptings couldn't be from God because you view God as someone who is not interested in helping you understand the world around you. He instead requires a kind of raw obedience that is always demanding that you act counter-intuitively, that you deny reality, that you rework the data to make it add up to a conclusion that doesn't make sense.
 
 The correct view of the Bible, of course, is that its teachings ought to help us make sense of life. They should resonate with reason and with common sense. This is not the same as saying that we should try to get the Bible to approve of whatever people feel like doing, which is what Christians understand gays and lesbians to be saying when they argue that they cannot help being homosexual. Christians are rightly concerned about having objective moral guidance to restrain whimsical and irresponsible behavior, and clearly there are many homosexuals who could use some moral guidance. But it is also clear when you hear gays and lesbians talk in depth about their homosexual feelings that this is not simply a case of people bent on doing what feels good to them and so morality can just take a hike.
 
 Any fair-minded person who reads the personal accounts of people who have battled fear and self-hatred to come to terms with their own homosexuality will be struck by the authenticity of such stories. It is amazing how often words like "honesty," "integrity" and "wholeness" are used unabashedly to describe this journey toward self-acceptance. (Would adulterers dare to defend their actions using such terms?) It certainly ought to make one question whether going around calling gay people "perverts" and characterizing them as sexual predators is really a very informed way of trying to bring biblical teaching to bear on the homosexual experience.
 
 Historically, the church has always recognized the validity of rational inquiry. The churchmen of old used to say that God has written two books, the Bible and the Book of Nature. God invites us to study the Bible to know the way of salvation; but he also invites us to apply our reason in studying his creation, i.e., the Book of Nature. That includes fields such as biology, mathematics, psychology, music, physics, etc.
 
 The church has always viewed the Bible as more authoritative than human reason, so when the two seem to clash the church will favor what it believes the Bible teaches. Historically speaking, then, the current resistance of the church to the arguments of homosexuals is a fairly typical response. Of course, it is a fallacy to think that just because the Bible is more authoritative than reason, that the conclusions of reason must be false. Sometimes the conclusions of reason are legitimate and ought to inform our interpretation of the Bible.
 
 For example in the 17th century, Galileo upset people's customary understanding of the universe when he taught Copernicus's theory that the sun and not the earth was at the center of the solar system. The church responded by opposing Galileo's observations about the earth's orbit around the sun because the Bible seemed to teach that the earth was stationary. Psalm 93:1, for example, says "the world also is established, that it cannot be moved." Much uproar and decrying of heresy followed Galileo's findings, resulting in his public trial and condemnation. It took a century or two, but the church did eventually come accept the Copernican theory, realizing that this biblical passage was simply a metaphorical way of talking about the security of our human existence under the everlasting rule of God, and was not an objective scientific commentary on the earth's relationship to the rest of the solar system.
 
 When it comes to considering whether the findings of reason should force an adjustment in our understanding of the Bible, the church typically drags its feet because certain interpretations tend to become almost traditional among Christians, and there is always resistance to changing what people are used to. But of a greater concern is that making such adjustments is always risky because a wrong move in that area could threaten to undermine more essential Christian teachings, such as those relating to the doctrine of salvation.
 
 Think of it like this. Christian theology is a system and all its doctrines fit logically together, like a giant jigsaw puzzle. The most important doctrines are the pieces located at the center of the puzzle. Modifying your understanding of one doctrine is like changing the shape of one of the puzzle pieces; the surrounding pieces also need to change shape a little to accommodate it. It's fine if it is only one of the outer pieces that needs some adjusting. Problems arise when the adjustment is so great that the subsequent chain reaction of adjustments threatens the central pieces; or when the piece that people are considering for adjustment is located too close to the center of the puzzle. A mistake could spell disaster, and the leaders of the church are aware of all the times in church history when such disastrous mistakes have been made.
 
 Unfortunately, the rise of liberal theology during the Enlightenment, when theologians began to use reason to deny the miracles of the Bible, was one such disaster that has caused conservative Christians to be suspicious of human reason to this day. Now denying the miracles of the Bible is pretty serious business, because belief in miracles is tied in with some of the most fundamental Christian doctrines such as the virgin birth, the resurrection, and the second coming of Christ. The outcome of this bitter controversy was the splitting of Christian theologians into liberal and conservative camps. The former denied the historicity of the biblical miracles and the latter was put in the defensive posture of having always to justify their belief in them.
 
 The outcome of this controversy was that conservative Christians felt burned by human reason, and began to view the conclusions of rational argumentation with great suspicion. Over the years they have became so jaded that it would be accurate to say that modern day fundamentalism is a thoroughly anti-intellectual and anti-rational movement. For these Christians hostility toward reason has practically become the hallmark of Bible belief. It reminds me of a plaque I saw in one fundamentalist pastor's study: "You don't need a PhD to believe the Bible, but to deny it you might."
 
 And so if Christians seem difficult to argue with, it is because many of them have adopted the odd idea that they can bypass rational persuasion and simply assert the Bible. To try to relate to people at the level of reason would be tantamount to a betrayal of faith, and so they are not concerned about relating. Their aim is to assault people with a truth-blitz, and if their audience rejects them it only confirms what rebellious heathen they are.
 
 With such a mentality, I wonder what hope there is that conservative Christians will ever be able to respond appropriately and intelligently to the increasing visibility of gays and lesbians in their communities, whose lives are dismantling all the old stereotypes, whose positive contributions to society are causing people to rethink their prejudices, and who will probably not be going away any time soon?
 
 The irrationality of Christians is not in their concern to defend the Bible. Their irrationality is in thinking that defending the Bible means closing their eyes to reality, because it is saying that defending the truth involves closing your eyes to truth. And for all their protesting that they believe in the Bible, is it not an admission of doubt rather than faith to go to such lengths to protect it from any kind of challenge or scrutiny? I mean, do we Christians believe in the God of the Bible, or do we secretly think he doesn't know what he's doing, and that's why we need to cover for him?
 
 It is unfortunate that conservative Christians have become so intellectually isolated from the debates that are currently taking place in our society. For if we really believe the Bible is God's inerrant and infallible truth, then of all people we ought to be in the best position to confront difficult questions, because we stand in a place of tremendous intellectual security. If what we learn about people's experiences with homosexuality seems to conflict with some of our traditional interpretations of Scripture, we ought to welcome the challenge. For we know that there must be answers out there if we believe that the God who authored the Bible is also the God who created humanity with all its complexities and mysteries. Real confidence in the Bible, and in the God who inspired it, ought to open up our minds, not close them.
